body.p:
Somerset Ky
March 21st 1863.
Governor Robinson
Dear Sir

As attorney for the Commonwealth I prosecuted one in the upon a charge of Manslaughter, Savage was convicted & sentenced to 10 years Confinement in the Penitentiary. He has now served out about one half of the time. I now write for the purpose of inducing you to pardon him and release him from the balance of the judgement of the Court. I feel impelled to this course from a concientious regard from the just administration of the law. The conduct of the deceased at the time he was slain was such as no man could have refrained from violence and altho technacally quilty of manslaughter Savage has already dearly & fully in my judgement expiated the crime. James SavageWayne Circuit Court informs me that he has already furnished you with a statement containing the substance of the testimony I therefore refrain from a repetition. And join him in an earnest appeal to you to let the poor fellow out. He was always a good boy honest and industrious, and stood well when the unfortunate affair occurred which has cost him his liberty.Senator Buster

I am yours Truly
E L Van Winkle

E. L. Vanwinkle
for Pardoning Savage
